text: REPORTER 1: Cancer treatment...

REPORTER 2: ..life-extending
prostate cancer...

REPORTER 3:
Much of the cancer crisis...

VIDEO INTERVIEWER: Will you explain
how vitamin C kills cancer cells?

Everyone has
some connection with cancer.

After all, nearly one in two of us
will get cancer
in our lifetimes.

Because cancer is seemingly
so common,

it gets a lot of attention
within the media.

And we often
get a lot of misinformation,
whether it's from family, friends,

what we read in the news
or what we see on TV.

And that can
actually be really detrimental

and harmful to someone
who has been diagnosed with cancer.

So how do you separate the myths
from the reality?
In my work as a nurse,

we do sometimes get asked
if sugar is a cause of cancer.

Now, this is taken
from a misunderstanding of something
known as the Warburg effect,

which is that cancer cells
seem to be very hungry for sugar

and seem to be very good
at breaking it down.

But if you cut sugar out
from your diet,

it doesn't stop
the cancer cells from growing.

But what about
artificial sweeteners,

things like aspartame
that are in diet drinks?
Do they cause cancer?

Well, the answer
is probably not, no.

The fact is that they are classed
as a class 2B carcinogen,

which means there's not enough
good evidence,
but they might have a health effect.

But in order to get enough
to even be close to being dangerous,

a person would have to drink
14 cans of fizzy drink a day.

But what we do know
is that sugar found in fizzy drinks
can cause weight gain.
And keeping a healthy weight
does impact our risk of cancer.

So, some people
think that mobile phones
can cause cancer.

And this is a misunderstanding
of the type of radiation,
a mobile phone causes.

Now, mobile phones have
electromagnetic radiation.
And although that might seem like
a really scary term,

lots of work has been done
to understand

whether those things
can be cancer causing.

And the answer
is a real categorical no.

This is a really
weak form of radiation.

And, you know, it isn't able
to affect our DNA
and lead to cancer.

Ionising radiation
is a little bit different.

It's something that
we're not exposed to very often -
things like airport scanners.

Um, actually, when we're in flight,
we're exposed to ionising radiation.
Ionising radiation

is also in things like X-rays
and scans that we may have.

But those are all
very low-level risks,

and we're only exposed
for very short periods of time.

It isn't a risk
to use your mobile phone

and, in fact, they can be
life-saving devices.

So, there's a lot
of misconceptions

around how we cook food and food
preparations and links to cancer.

So, things like,
If I heat up my food

in a plastic container
in the microwave,
is that going to give me cancer?

But I guess I'm kind of here to say,
no, we don't have any evidence
that any of those things are true.

My granny used
to tell me that burning toast

could increase your cancer risk.
Well, when you burn food,

what you do is you create
a chemical called acrylamide.

And the good news is that
there is no good evidence

that acrylamide
causes cancer either.

So you can really burn your toast
on both sides if you want.
Heating food in plastic containers

and, indeed, heating food
in a microwave -
both of those are absolutely fine.

In fact, in one experiment,
what some scientists did is

they heated food in a plastic
container for very long time

and no chemicals transferred
into the food.

The real fact remains that actually
there are not that many things
that cause cancer.

The number-one thing that causes
cancer above all else is ageing.

The older we are, the more likely
we are to develop cancer.

So making sure
people have the right information
is very important.

We want to try and dispel
some of the myths around cancer
so that people are not scared,

that they will access services
and seek help if they need to.

It's so important that if you have
any symptoms or signs

that you may be potentially
worried about,

or that are persistent
for more than three weeks,

that you please go and see
your health professional

because it's so important
to get the right tests
and investigations done,

because we know that
early diagnosis saves lives.
